div.head:
3590. Robert Southey to Grosvenor Charles Bedford, 24 December 1820Address: To/ G. C. Bedford Esqre/ Exchequer
Endorsements: 24 Decr 1820/ with Ode for 1821; 24 Decr. 1820
MS: Bodleian Library, MS Eng. Lett. d. 47. ALS; 7p.
Unpublished.
div.p: For once I send you an Ode which is good for something, tho you may not think it fit for its purpose, & may very likely xxx <to> be disposed to recommend some sing-song about the infant Princess Elizabeth.Southey’s duty as Poet Laureate was to produce a New Year’s Ode for 1821; his poem was later published as ‘The Warning Voice. Ode II’ in The Englishman’s Library: Comprising a Series of Historical, Biographical and National Information (London, 1824), pp. 384–389. Princess Elizabeth of Clarence (1820–1821) was briefly third in line to the throne, after her father, William, Duke of Clarence (1765–1837; King of the United Kingdom 1830–1837; DNB). She was born on 10 December 1820 and died aged 12 weeks. As she was born six weeks prematurely, Southey was perhaps wise to be cautious about celebrating her in verse. To which anticipated recommendation I now reply, that I could not venture upon so precarious a subject as that of an infants life, lest the infant should die & so the sing-song be like a new coloured coat in a sudden court general mourning: – & moreover that if the infant lives till the birth<day>George IV’s ‘official’ birthday, next celebrated on 23 April 1821; Southey believed he would have to write birthday, as well as New Year’s Odes, as Poet Laureate in the new reign. that will be the fitter opportunity: my theory being that the New Years ode should always be national the B. Day courtly.

I desire Shield to or rather advise him, to begin at the 7th stanza, & take as much or as little of what follows as he likes.It was Shield’s duty to set some of these verses to music in case a court performance was ordered (though this practice had been suspended since 1810). Send this to him forthwith with a few lines of civility. – I shall print it, with other such things as garnish for my Dialogues.Sir Thomas More: or, Colloquies on the Progress and Prospects of Society (1829). They did not include ‘The Warning Voice. Ode II’, but did feature six engravings from views of the Lake District by William Westall. By the bye ask Murray to show you Westalls drawings for the said Dialogues.

There is an extract in the newspaper from Belzoni which makes me long to see the book.Giovanni Battista Belzoni (1778–1823; DNB), explorer and pioneering Egyptologist; author of Narrative of the Operations and Recent Discoveries Within the Pyramids, Temples, Tombs and Excavations in Egypt and Nubia (1820). Extracts were being published in the press; for example, ‘Singular Phenomena of Egypt’, Morning Chronicle, 19 December 1820.

When you see Gifford tell him that I have not received the Notes on Rio de Janeiro, & that xx if I had them, I should be at work for him.Southey had proposed an article on Brazilian travel writing for the Quarterly Review; it was not written. He had probably asked Gifford to send him John Luccock (1770–1826), Notes on Rio de Janeiro, and the Southern Parts of Brazil: Taken During a Residence of Ten Years in that Country, from 1808 to 1818 (1820), no. 1645 in the sale catalogue of Southey’s library.

closer.salute: God bless you – a merry Xmas & a happy year.

lg.l: In a vision I was seized,
In the stillness that is felt
Thro the air I was borne away;
Were the wide wings of Darkness spread.
Like stars in the bosom of a lake;
Like the sound of the sea
Where it rakes on a pebbly stone <shore>.
A Voice from the darkness went forth
Son of Man look below! it said
As the Patriarch in his dream
On their ministry of love, The biblical patriarch, Jacob, received a vision of a ladder reaching from heaven to earth, with angels moving up and down it, Genesis 28: 10–19.
So saw I where a way
To the black abyss of bale,
To the dolorous region of Death.
Which were thrown on their hinges back.
And the gleam of sulphurous fires
The Spirits of Evil were trooping up:
And they bore with them curses & plagues.
And the seeds of strife & death.
Son of Man, look up! said the Voice,
Seen like a pillar of light
That slants from a broken sky.
That heavenly way by clouds was closed,
Heavy & thick & dark, with thunder charged:
Who raised in menacing act his aweful arm.
Woe to the City where Faction reigns!
Woe to the Land where Sedition prevails!
Woe to the Nation whom Hell deceives!
Eyes have they, & will not see;
Ears have they, & will not hear;
Hearts have they, & will not feel!
Woe to the People who close their eyes!
Woe to the People who shut their ears!
Woe to the People who harden their hearts!
But from that City then behold
Her snow-white wings upon the dusky air
Shone, like the waves which glow
Around the midnight keel in liquid light.
Upward her supplicating arms were spread;
And as her face to heaven
Loose like a Comets radiant tresses hung
Not yet, O Lord! not yet,
Not yet! the tutelary Angel cried;
For I must plead with thee for this poor land, –
The mother still of noble minds,
Not yet, O Lord, not yet
Thou who hast set thy Bow
Not yet, O Lord, pour out
Here purchased by thy Martyrs’ precious blood,The Church of England and its martyrs, especially those Protestants executed in the reign of Mary I (1516–1558; Queen of England 1553–1558; DNB).
For that well-orderd frame of equal Laws
So oft hath been extended heretofore,
The household Virtues that in secret here,
Like sweetest violets, send their fragrance forth,
Oh! wilt thou quench the light
The nations who in darkness sit
And in the shadow of death?
Oh! wilt thou stop the heart
Wilt thou seal the eye of the World? –
Upon a land so long the dear abode
Of freedom, knowledge, virtue, faith approved, –
Plead with me, O ye Dead, whose sacred dust
Is laid to rest within her hallowed ground,
Plead with me for your country, suffering now
Beneath such loathsome plaguesThe ten plagues inflicted on the Egyptians to persuade them to let the Israelites leave the country, Exodus 7–12.
As ancient Egypt in her slime
Plead with me at this hour,
Ye who are doomd upon this fateful spot
Or children of a ruined realm, to shame
(For this is on the issue of the hour!)
Plead with me, unborn Spirits, that the wrath
Join in my supplication Seas & Lands
The generous Nation strove.A reference to Britain’s long war against France 1793–1815.
For whose deliverance in the Spanish fields
And that Brabantine plainThe Battle of Waterloo on 18 June 1815. Waterloo was part of the medieval Duchy of Brabant.
Join with me Africa,Britain had abolished the slave trade in 1807 and was trying to persuade other countries to do so.
For here hath thy redemption had its birth!
And ye remotest Isles & Continent,The Pacific islands and Australia.
Where the glad tidings of the Gospel truth,
Join with me now to wrest
The thunderbolt from that uplifted arm!
Plead with me, Earth & Ocean! at this hour!
And for thy benefactress, thou O Earth!
Where thro the clear blue sky the silver Moon
A healing influence reachd my heart
And I felt in my soul
That the voice of the Angel was heard.
